WRITING.TEXT: Just like food, film has an expiration date, after which it may or may not perform as it is supposed to. Sometimes things will work out just fine (as is the case of this picture), but others there might be A LOT OF grain or weird colour casts - in this roll some pictures ended up too green in the shadows. It is a fun thing to shoot expired film because of the unpredictability. By the way, 9 years is really not that long, I've seen people around shooting stuff expired for 50+ years.

You can just do it normally, but you can also push it for extra grainy weirdness. Or develop it yourself with some different chemicals. All in all, expired film works exactly like regular film, only more unpredictable and most likely with loss on IQ.

Even if they did not pay anything directly or indirectly to the government - which they do as explained -, free basic education is a human right guaranteed by the International Covenant on Social and Economical Rights, to which the USA is a party. It must be provided to anyone within the territory or jurisdiction of the USA, irrespective of the person's legal status as that would violate the non-discrimination principle. This is an international obligation which is also appliable to the domestic law as interpreted by the Supreme Court.

It is indeed, but since it's a human right it cannot be denied to anyone for political convenience. Human rights standards are the limit to policy-making. Besides, if it were denied that would be unfair to children, because their parents took the decision to emmigrate, not them. Furthermore, undocumented immigrant status is already a gigantic hassle, specially in the US, so I'm also not sure whether denying them access to public services would be an effective deterrent to undocumented immigration, I think it would rather worsen the life of people who already have it really difficult.

WRITING.TEXT: I have the non-gIII version, which is bigger and heavier, but I don't mind it, it feels like it's built for a war, really solid. The rangefinder is exceptionally bright and the lens is as sharp as you can get for anything under 1000USD (the 1.7 aperture also gets beautiful bokeh). The lightmeter is quirky and often times a little off, so I always set it one stop down (this way if it gets right, it'll overexpose by only one stop and if it goes a little wrong it'll either get exposition right or overexpose by two stops, which is no big deal with C-41/B amp;W film). Canon's quickload mechanism works a treat, you basically can't mess up the film and it gets you 38 exposures in a normal roll!! I found mine for a little over 100USD (in Brazil), but the lens was in a deplorable state, so I paid extra 40USD for a complete CLA and it looks as good as new. Worth every penny. 100 to 150 pounds seems a little on the expensive end, but it's worth it if you're paying for a mint camera.

You're absolutely right, but sanctioning a country shouldn't mean severing diplomatic ties with it. On the contrary, keeping a representative to mediate negotiations between one country (or the international community) and other, is absolutely essential to make sure it complies with human rights standards. Not only because you can only achieve it with negotiation - what good are sanctions if there aren't any ways to suspend them? -, but mainly because without diplomatic relations there's no reliable way to observe, investigate and control the policies implemented in the direction of achieving human rights' standards. Really, sanctions are just a kind of "coercive negotiation".

They speak dutch in Suriname, and english in Guiana, other than that every other country (except, of course, Brazil) in south america speaks spanish. Slight exception to Paraguay, where Guarany is also an official language. The fench Guiana belongs to France, so they're politically Europe. Other countries like Trinadad and Tobago, Haiti, etc, are in the Caribean islands, which is not south america. Mexico, Canada and the US are in north america, which is a geographical distinction (South, North, Central and Caribean). Anything between Mexico and Colombia within the mainland is central america. Other than that, there's also a linguistical-cultural distinction, in which Canada and the US are part of the anglo-saxon american and the rest is latin america (even if english, dutch or french speaking, like Haiti, Jamaica or Barbados). By the way, although Haiti's official language is French, they speak Cr #233;ole, which is borderline incomprehensible to francophones.

WRITING.TEXT: I know it is one of the most beloved watches out here and a beautiful piece of horology with its in-house movement and staggering attention to detail ...but It's pretty much identical to a Stowa Antea, which came before it. Nomos also does not reference Stowa in their description of the Tangente. The question is: why should a Tangente be more acceptable than a Invicta? Both are homages to other well-known watches, and have their own level of craftsmanship and also their own movements.

The owner may or may not be entitled to claim the watch depending on whether 2 years under the shop's care meant that he waived his right to claim it back. If he did, well, then it's yours; but if he didn't then he may claim it back directly from you BUT you should be able to petition against the watch shop (or the owners, or whover legally answers for it after it closed down) and retrieve your 500 bucks, unless they prove you bought it with knowledge that the owner could show up and retrieve the watch (prepare yourself against this allegation just in case). Disclaimer: my point is not totally valid, it's subject to change depending on your local and national laws. I'm a brazilian law student, but I tried to keep it as close as possible to general rules of private law that are more or less universally applicable. Edit: all of this sounds too convenient. The shop closing down, the owner randomly showing up the downscaled price... If I were you I would also search for a lawyer and prepare against frauds.

Looks legit to me, but you should check whether there is a wave-pattern in the dial to be sure (it can't be seen from the photos). Aside from that, everything looks all-right. If you're in doubt check yourself for official photos and compare them. What's most important, though, is that it feels real. By the weight alone you should have an idea. Also, make sure to check the smoothness of the sweep (it should be pretty smooth albeit a little tiny bit tickly), make daily measurements to make sure it's accurate (if it deviates more than +/- 15s a day you should double-check), and finally inspect closer - preferably with a magnifying glass - and check for any quality-control flaws, everything should be absolutely impecable if it's a real omega. If after all that checking and double-checking you still have any doubts, find a trustworthy watchmaker to remove the caseback, take pictures of the movement and check the authenticity yourself or send a picture of the movement here.

Assuming you'd be your everyday regular gun-for-hire, I'd say a G-shock of some kind, waterproof to the bone, unbreakable, reliable, functional and sweats practicality. Now, if you're talking high-profile international hitman you should be able to blend in well within the elite environment of your targets. No G-shocks on cocktail parties with CEOs and drug lords, please! In this case, you'd ideally have a different watch for each job, but if you were to need an all-rounder (for whichever reason), there should be some requirements: 1. It must be tough, you may be at a cocktail at a given time and then fleeing in the jungle right after. 2. It must be subdued, you don't want anyone noticing you too much, so no all-gold yacht-masters. 3. It has to be classy, you will be meeting REALLY important people (and perhaps killing them). 4. Ideally it'd be a conversation starter so you'd blend in along the *connoisseurs* in the circle. 5. It requires reliability because, well, it can't break. 6. You need to be able to wear it with a tuxedo or casual attire - no one knows whether your next target is at the French Riviera or at the Vienna Opera. 7. Yet it needs to be somewhat flashy so people will know you belong there - no obscure brands, few people will ever know your $100k vintage 1920s Vacheron Constantin is any better than your grandfather's beaten up Timex. IMO the Rolex Explorer 1 fits all the boxes, it's reliable, precise, tough, subdued, classy yet sporty and has a very interesting story behind it, you can also dress it up or down with different straps. Other options are the Submariner, Seamaster 300, or pretty much anything any Bond has ever worn (with the exception of the awkward digital Omegas and Seikos).

I find it really bizarre that the child gets punished for not being vaccinated. Refusing to vaccinate is the parent's fault! Why limit the child right to education when the parents are the stupid ones? There should be a fine for the parents who don't vaccinate their children, but restricting the access to education is just dumb.
Ok I get that not vaccinating your child is bad and stupid and should be punished but do you honestly think it amounts to child neglect?

Not all vaccines are against contagious diseases, and even so, a child infected with a contagious disease should be granted leave from school for as long as the doctors reccomend, not outright lose its right to education. Besides, it doesn't make sense to punish children because they may (or may not) be infected in the future.
Good point, though I'm still not sure whether the number of unvaccinated children is large enough to undermine herd immunity...
Geez, people

That's a good point right there. Nevertheless I still think there are preventive ways to avoid denial of vaccination that do not deprive children of their rights. If there were fines against the parents, with high interest in case they don't get paid, then children would still go to school while the parents would, in a short timespan, have no way other than vaccinate the child.
Wow I didn't expect it to be so drastic! Perhaps there's still a less damaging alternative, but while I don't find one I can't help but agree with you.

I really liked it at first because of the intro scene with the progressive and emotional soundtrack, mainly because it had very interesting location shots that established the ambient of the show nicely. It honestly reminded me of some Ghibili movies like castle in the sky, pony or spirited away. Then it came the introductory dialogue: "this is where our story begins" - and where my interested ended. It was followed by a poor OP with boring music and no animation but random shots scattered throughout the show that have no relevance. When the show started I was already so bored I didn't bother to look at the screen, but the few glances I gave showed bland backgrounds, little to no animation effort and generic character designs. There were some positives points, though. Besides the intro scene, I enjoyed when the blonde guy pretty much declared to the class rep (ok her char design is actually really really cute with the braids and whatnot). Also, the establishing shots kept their high level, but were mostly used to cover up for the lack of quality in animation. BUT WAIT I'M NOT OVER THERE'S STILL THE SHITTIEST PART What. The. Fuck. Happened. When the blonde guy was speaking in the background about meeting in the convenience store while RANDOM SHOTS OF OTHER UNKNOWN PEOPLE WERE SHOWING??? I think this lasted for a good minute or two and had NO REASON. I don't know who those people are, I'm sure they'll never show up again so WHY GOD WHY? Also, the class rep and the main girl in the library speaking in the background while random shots of the rep reading manga in the aisle from EVERY. ANGLE. POSSIBLE. Pointless. Tl;dr: mostly bland, the intro scene was interesting, as was the last one, they tried too hard to cover up for the bad animation, two garbage scenes.

I don't think Tomo and Yoichi are that close to Victor and Yuri. At 25 he could never hope to be anything in the ice-skating carreer and then BANG his idol appears naked at his inn' hot spring and what a ~~butt~~ scene. On the other hand, Tomo and Yoichi have also an endearing relationship, but it comes from a completely different place. Yes, Yoichi is Tomo's idol almost as much as Victor is for Yuri, but the fact that Tomo is just starting makes all the difference. There is no hopelessness to be overcome, nor any adult-to-adult relationship. It's rather a senpai-to-kouhai supporting thing.

But comfort is the only rule here. 2) Nylon straps (NATO, Perlon or Cordura) are strictly casual, they're a good wear when it's hot because of breathability - they can also handle water. Bracelets are also breathable, handle water well, and can also be worn formally (though that's a slight faux-pas). Leather is the most formal, specially textured leather, contrast stitching dresses it down a bit, but keep it out of the water and heat. 3) Definitely. President Putin wears Fliegers, for example. The strict dress watch etiquette is not much of a thing, mainly since Bond rocked a submariner with a tuxedo - on a NATO no less. Just keep it to simple tool watches, you can't dress up a Navitimer. 4) No, I keep them on display at my desk. 5) Not really, just keep it simple and wear whichever way you like it. Hey OP I think it's wonderful you shared such deep and personal issues with all of us and I wholeheartedly empathize with you in much of your experience. Sex is definetely something weird for me too although I'm not really repulsed by it and believe I could do it to please a significant other. I understand particularly how you feel towards porn, and that's what creeped me out the most about sex as soon as I came in contact with it. For many years I couldn't stand the idea of sex because in my mind it was supposed to be abusive in order to be pleasant, however recently I came accross many alossexual friends - specially feminists - who deeply criticized the idea of sex as portraied in pornography. With this new contact, I managed to figure out it can actually be something pleasant for some (most?) people. From there on I started being more open towards the idea of having sex, albeit it didn't change at all my (lack of) will to seek it. I think that in this particular point your experience says a lot about the intersections between sexuality and gender violence. The way sex is sold, as a male dominated market that reiterates th subjagation of women, makes many of us very uncomfortable and unable to develop a healthy way of understanding sexuality. This is not to say, of course, that assexuality is caused by direct or indirect exposition to sex, but rather that this kind of exposition makes many of us assexuals unable to understand alossexual desires and it is very challenging to overcome it since the idea of sex as a kind of violence is aggressively marketed mainly towards us, the male audience.
Just because you don't want to have children yourself, don't force your life choices into others whether ace or not, I thought that was just common decency

WRITING.TITLE: Question from a cis white male ace.
WRITING.TEXT: Hello guys, I was talking to a friend of mine recently and the topic diverged to whether I am or am not part of an oppressed community. Now, don't get her wrong, she was very respectful and all and it didn't go in the "you're not oppressed enough" talk. Rather, she argued that as a cis white male who so far only had relationships with women, I am not perceived as a member of the queer community, thus I'm not oppressed. Although of course aces are frequently subjected to corrective rapes, correction therapies and sorts of exclusions, I started to think she might have a point. The thing is, I have never *personally* suffered any kind of violence. My friends and family are very respectful and compassionate about my sexuality, and even with strangers I never felt much more than slightly bothered by their denial of assexuality. However, I know my experiences are not necessarily universal. That's why I'd like to know from this community whether any of you know of or have suffered any kind of discrimination or violence agains cis white male assexuals. Thanks in advance!

The thing is when it comes to actual acts of violence against assexual people, I do have a feeling that women and trans people are targets to corrective rapes due to their assexuality (although I don't think there's any data to back that up). That's why I asked the question. Is the violence against cis male white aces just people bothering us or is it something else?

I don't think that was my friend's point. It's rather that the *seen as* is what constitutes oppression from a social and objective standpoint, not individually but rather as a collective. If I am to further my question, it'd be: what exactly constitutes the *seen as* in the assexual community? If nothing, than is it possible to exist a kind of oppression that relies necessarily on intersection? The answer to the second one would be obviously be yes, since for assexual women and trans people corrective rape is a thing, and for non-heteroromantic assexuals, invasive corrective therapy is also a thing. But I'm not 100% sure about the first one.
That makes a lot of sense, I didn't think through this point of view. I can take corrective sexual activity as being a thing (especially given the conditions for male socialization).
Yes, but I'm also politically defined by some categories. This does not rid me of me individuality, but rather allows me to see myself as part of a bigger group.
Nuclear waste, people. It's baaaaad. This is in no way a support to the actions carried out by the activists.
True, but I believe that from a non-lawyer/politologist/sociologist perspective, the terms law, state, civil society and organized groups might be very similar.

Tbh I think this decision and this ending is perfect. The whole show is not about individual heroism, but reflects on the need of a collectivity to cause change in a system. Akane knew that. She saw with her own eyes what happened to Kogami when he tried to do it. I differ from digi, where I believe Akane is a true revolutionary for that. Her choice was to not get rid of sybyl, as it'd only bring chaos and take society to it's primal state, from which it would take centuries to reorganize in a no less oppressive state. But it was also to not merge with it and keep the status quo. By walking back Akane realized herself was not enough, that she needed the help with others to bring society to a brighter and more human future. I only loathe that the second season was not at all about this collective effort both within and against sybyl.

First, Human Rights are not ideals, they're norms, law, legally binding. The phillipines are a contracting state on the international covenant on civil and political rights, and even if they weren't, the prohibition of extrajudicial killing is a rule for every single country in the world. Far from every moral argument, Duterte's drug policy is *straight up illegal*. Second, if processing and jailing drug users and traffickers would be a problem (as it is a problem in Latin America, btw I'm brazilian so I know it first hand), then why not legalization? It doesn't have to happen from day to night, but it's a path recommended internationally and with high rates of success, yes, even in developing countries - see how uruguay reduced drastically the number of prisoners and drug-related offenses processes after only marijuana legalization. Of course the policy would jave to be adapted to south-east asian reality, but it's tried and tested.

If your whole argument is based on rampant corruption and system inneficiency, I don't see what actually impedes you from standing for solutions of this problem rather than just giving up and accepting mass executions of unjudged presumed drug traffickers as the only way out. It's true I don't understand much of the history of south east asia, but all of the problems you ennumerated as the starting point of your analysis (drug abuse, corruption, and system inneficiency), are also present in latin america.

I'm still not comviced it's the only way for developing countries. Once again, look at Uruguay, they solved the drug problem without having to resort to any kind of extrajudicial executions. Portugal is also a good example after the decriminalization and shift from crime to health policy, although maybe not the best for comparisons, as a membership to the EU has a lot to do with that. Still, public policies are challenging, even if it is necessary to adapt to the east-asian context, that's something that can be done. Of course it would take a long time but it's possible to preserve the rights of *everyone* and get rid of drugs. Policies should aim for that, not taking the easy way out (for some, because it certainly isn't easy for drug users, alleged traffickers and their families). Politics is no Occam's Razor.

I think OP is theoretically correct, but this downplays the many ways of restricting citizenship within a country. It's naive to believe that after Israel became a single state in the region the government would grant all palestinian/arab residents citizenship. Israel could, for example, restrict citizenship to sons of original israeli decent (jus sanguini), which would significantly impair most papestinians of acquiring citizenship. On another example, it could adopt an ethno-national citizenship policy, where only members of certain ethnicities are allowed citizenship (see what Myanmar is doing with the Rohingya). Also possible would be the treatment of palestinians as jordanian migrants, with no right to citizenship under strict immigration laws. Tl;dr: there are endless ways to restrict citizenship, israel would somehow manage to not grant it to palestinians.

Free speech doesn #8217;t mean saying what you want, there #8217;s no place in the world that doesn #8217;t establish some sort of barrier to the exercize of this right. I have a hard time believing the judge #8217;s decision will hold up. All in all this is a short analysis on why you SHOULDN #8217;T make contracts with diplomats (unless in their country of origin). Article 31 (a) on the Convention on Diplomatic relations states that diplomats are not immune #8220;To real actions relating to private immovable properties situated in the territory of the receiving State, UNLESS he holds it (...) FOR THE PURPOSES OF THE MISSION #8221; It #8217;s very well settled in International Law that the house of a diplomat is a place that also serves the purpose of the mission. This is because it #8217;s a place where diplomatic reunions and dinners may take place, as well a place where privacy should be granted for the diplomat to freely communicate with its staff while outside the premises (this is essential in case of diplomatic emergencies for example). Also, systematically speaking, art. 30 of the same Convention makes the house of a diplomat enjoy #8220;the same inviolability (...) as the premisses of the mission #8221;. Which is further argument on why its considered to be a place for uses of the mission. All things taken, art. 31 (a) also excludes inviolabiloty in the case of REAL claims. Real claims involve property, so diplomats are not inviolable to claims regarding the status of proprietary of real-state. Obviously, rent claims do not consist real claims, but rather contractual ones, to which there are no exceptions on immunnity.

The introduction of Frederica in this episode was brilliant. I #8217;ve only seen the OVA quite a long time ago and don #8217;t remember if it was the same or slightly different, but it comes to show that if one criticism can be made on LotGA #8217;s writing it is the lack of female characters, but it makes up for introducing the most amazing and well constructed ones. Take for instance Yang #8217;s slight discompusure when she comes into the room and presents herself (which is shoved away immediately after she asked if there was something unusual). This minimal facial expression does two things. First, it builds up on Yang #8217;s character as this praxis-oriented admiral fascinated with history that on the one hand is alien to the perspective of women in battlefield, but on the other understanding that this doesn #8217;t change anythig at all given that she was put there on her accolades alone. Second, it shows Frederica #8217;s grounded compusure and firm treatment, who doesn #8217;t care about putting her superior in a tight and akward situation, if it is to stand her ground. The second part is further explored on the Rosenritter HQ scene, but this doesn #8217;t mean that this scene was without purpose. It strikingly poses a comparison between the treatment of women in the FPA and the Empire. Wherein on the first case the more progressive ideals allowed then to get a military carreer and strive for political activism, the old and conservative Rudolphean institutions treats them as #8220;marriage commodities #8221; (see Annerose and, more interestingly, Hildegard on the OVA). Certainly former Empire citizens do cater to more sexist and harrassing atitudes, besides of course totaling disrespecting the rank and position of Frederica. This is just one perspective to read those two scenes of course, which manage to tell so much in very little. Writing and directing like this gives not only more depth to the charaters but also builds a world which resonates much more with our own. The way LotGA in general, and new adaptation in particular, manages to bring so many larger-than-life themes in such a tight and natural package is what makes it a widely acclaimed series.

Ok, that #8217;s a complicated law. Surely sex without consent is rape by any moral or societal standards, but legally this is a very complicated situation. In criminal law, as a matter of principle and justice, the Court has to assume the accused is innocent, unless proven otherwise. In this case, it means the initial assumption is: there was consent. How is it possible for prosecutors then to prove that there wasn #8217;t? You can blindly trust on the alleged victim #8217;s word, of course, and have the alleged perpetrator prove that there was consent, but isn #8217;t that the same thing as destroying the innocence principle altogether? I might be deadly wrong, and the law might be more precise and well written than what I could assume from reading the article, but if it is like that, any judge faced with a rape case will be forced to take one of the two routes: 1) destroy the innocence principle and assume whatever the alleged victim is saying is true without further proof or 2) simply disregard the accusation because consent is presumed and can #8217;t be possibly disproved (this is devil #8217;s proof, namely to allege that something didn #8217;t happen). Aggression and coercion on the other hand would have ne proven existent on a given case by the prosecutor, which actually makes it easier to the accusation. This law is either a violation of the right #8217;s of the accused or a way less effective mean of punishing rape. In either case bad, [trump] VERY BAD [/trump]

If all is fine with your body, not having sexual desire is ok and there #8217;s no need to panic. Asexuals are out there, as I am one. Responding with force would be a very dumb move. Spying and meddling in political affairs are a very grey zone in international law and governments can do it freely without attracting much attention. In fact, in terms of international relations it is way more lucrative to let it be done to you so you can do it back to them. Spy games are the norm in international affairs, some just happen to be more public than others, and often in purpose. Using this or other further espionage incidents as a ground for the use of force puts america on the wrong side of thing, because you can #8217;t use force for other reason than to impair the illegitimate use of force against yourself. Putting america in the wrong side of things and russia in the right one (as they #8217;d legimatelly defend themselves) turns all the factors in favor of russia. It #8217;d be hard if not impossible to justify any NATO action on the grounds of illegal use of force by the US, and Russia could rely on allied countries to retaliate, for example.

The NATO acts accordingly to legal mechanisms subject to judicial review in each of the member states #8217; justice system. France, for example, wouldn #8217;t be able to send its troops even if the president wanted unless the action was due to collective self-defence. If it tried, the french judiciary could and possibly would just bar the sending of troops in lack of a legal ground for action. The same for most if not all NATO member states, they would see themselves inactive unless self-defence was sufficiently proved.

Transgender is not necessarily about body dysmorphia, which IS a mental disorder. Wherein transgender people often feel dysmorphia, some are completely comfortable with their own bodies or not uncomfortable enough to the point of being unhealthly obsessed with body change (such as in anorexia). It is more about the displacement in relation to expected social gender roles than to the body per se.

Playing videogames to the point of damaging obsession might as well be a mental disorder, also the number of suicides with homossexual people is also significantly bigger than in the straight community without meaning homossexuality is a disease. You might as well argue trans people are suiciding because they are being treated as sick anomalies. I don #8217;t know where you want to get with this argument.

But are they emotionally unwell because they are transgender or because they are treated badly for being transgender? Certainly trans people who have been treated with love and acceptance are not unstable, much on the contrary.

Do them? The left-wing argument I #8217;m for is that men and women (and trans and cis) are equal, but the different treatment each get in society is different. Brainwise I think it #8217;s pretty clear there #8217;s no difference (in the biological organ that is, maybe in its functioning, but it #8217;s also pretty unclear how much of the brain functioning is socially determined).

That #8217;s an interesting argument, but even those lucky trans people are not living in isolation from an overall transphobic society, which in its turn impacts their mental well-being. It #8217;s not so much transsexuality #8217;s fault as it is transphobia #8217;s.

Most certainly, I #8217;m not challeging the statistics, but the causality. Transexuality is not the cause of the mental unwelness in trans people, but rather the outside treatment they receive for being trans.

Also that #8217;s some shady edit. Still doesn #8217;t unprove my point, after all, isn #8217;t the lack of acceptance the cause of chemical imbalance? And going on a tangent, it #8217;s still pretty damn unclear whether depression is even related to any brain chemical imbalance, as it has been shown that many individuals with perfectly balanced brain chemistry still may show symptons of depression.

Well all those factors come often paired with body dysphoria which is an actual mental health condition, but not to be reduced to transexuality itself (many trans do not have it and live well with their bodies, just not their social roles). Besides it #8217;s been pretty clear over the years in the transexual movement that they themselves do not want it to be considered and a disease and regard the #8220;treatments #8221; for it highly inadequate. Treating transexuality as a disease puts the blame on the individual for being trans and doesn #8217;t focus on actual problems, such as body dysphoria or depression. Also, even if trans people are met sometimes woth acceptance by their close family, friend and colleagues, this does not mean they are being well treated overall. Transphobia is rampant and a trans person is well more likely to be poorly treated by other if not most people outside their close social circles, which put them still in a more sensible mental health condition. Tl;dr: the problem is not transexuality itself, but other things that come associated with it.

It would, most countries abide by the so called "active personality principle" meaning that they have criminal jurisdiction over nationals who commited a crime anywhere. So if a US citizen kills someone on a raft in international waters he can be liable under US law. As I said: most countries, however I do not know of a single one that does not abide by this rule. The funny situation would be that of a stateless person commiting a crime against another stateless person in outer space, that'd maybe be left unpunishable.

If your rover is unregistered, it'd probably escape US jurisdiction in outer space, as the "flagged ship rule" applies only to vessels registered within a state. Not OP though, OP would be liable for any violation of FAA rules.

WRITING.TITLE: [Portuguese] Rio #8217;s 200 year old national museum caught on fire

WRITING.TEXT: As a research assistant myself this image will never leave my head. First they cut all scholarships and now they destroy our history and culture. It makes me wanna puke, and some candidates are even speaking of cutting off the ministry of culture and the ministry of research amp; technology. It #8217;s just plain rotten.

WRITING.TITLE: Rio #8217;s 200 year old national museum hit by massive fire

WRITING.TEXT: All because of a complete lack of funding for cultural heritage and public research. Some candidates for the forthcoming elections even have the guts of saying they want to get rid of the ministry of culture. Despicable.
Even they came back in this decision a little later. It is and always was criminally underfunded, but getting rid of it as a proposition for the candidacy is a new low.

Thankfully nobody got hurt, there were only 4 security guards on duty that escaped before the fire went berserk and the museum closed for visitations a couple hours before. However, firefighters are having a hard time finding extra water supplies so they #8217;re currently only doing the fasade to try and save the structure, but the fire is stil spreading along the sides of the building. Due to severe underfunding the museum couldn #8217;t install fire prevention and control mechanisms that were necessary.

They didn #8217;t fail, they planned it. I #8217;ve been working as a research assistant in Brazil ever since I got into college. The underfunding of public research and cultural instutions is planned and often times even cheered and regarded as a bad use of public funds. Well, this is what happens.
